The chemical fixation of CO2 into high value-added chemicals is of significant potential and sustainability to address the energy and ecological issues. To achieve great catalytic performance on the transformation of CO2, it is pivotal to strategically integrating several multifunctional and synergetic functionalities into the catalyst design and catalytic system construction. Herein, the poly(ionic liquid)-hierarchical porous covalent organic framework (PIL-HPCOF) hybrids were successfully synthesized via the formation of HPCOF through hard-template method, followed by in-situ polymerization of mono-vinyl decorated ionic liquids (ILs). The resultant PIL-HPCOF hybrids possess excellent versatility, with micropores providing high surface area to enhance CO2 uptake capacity and macropores supplying sufficient pore volume to promote mass transport of substrates. As a proof of concept, the conversion of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates was selected as a model reaction, which catalytic performance was obviously promoted by using PIL-HPCOF hybrids as the catalyst as compared to those of independent PIL and the PIL-COF hybrids with only micropores. Thus, it enables such a metal-free catalysis proceeds under much mild conditions (CO2 (1 MPa), 90 °C) and with broad substrates tolerance. These results supply the basis to design efficient and stable catalysts for CO2 conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Poly(ionic liquid)s Covalent organic frameworks Hierarchical pores CO2 conversion Cycloaddition reaction 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2), known as a typical greenhouse gas, is also an abundant, nontoxic, and inexpensive C1 feedstock [1,2]. In the past decades, great efforts have been dedicated to convert CO2 into highly value-added fine chemicals in both academic and industrial fields [3,4]. Owing to its naturally thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness, however, a large amount of energy investment is required to convert CO2 and the development of efficient chemical fixation process for CO2 remains a huge challenge [5,6]. In this domain, the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides is identified as excellent strategy for CO2 utilization with 100% atom efficiency, which also represents the greener replacement of traditional phosgene in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates functioning as valuable solvents and intermediates in industry [7,8]. To date, the documented catalytic systems without metal and co-catalyst generally require rigorous reaction conditions because of the thermodynamically stable and chemical inertness of CO2. The strategies to promote the performance in the metal-free catalyzed cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides could be classified into two general types: (a) Introduce various hydrogen bond donor groups (hydroxy [9–12], amino [13,14] and carboxyl [15–17]) into the ionic catalyst (mainly the cation counterpart), which cooperates with the anion (mainly the halides) in accelerating the rate-limiting step of ring-opening epoxides [18]. The decorated hydrogen bond donors can also stabilize the potential transition states and intermediates during the reaction process [19,20]. Such a method for designing well-defined molecular catalysts has also been widely used in constructing the structural motifs of highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts. (b) Enrich CO2 concentration around the catalytic sites to improve the cycloaddition efficiency since the cycloaddition exhibits a first-order dependence on the concentration of CO2 and epoxides [21]. In this respect, the introduction of ionic moieties and Brønsted base sites, such as amines, imines, imidazoles, and triazines, have been documented to increase the affinity of CO2, thus facilitating its conversion [22–27]. Besides, the reaction efficiency can be adjusted by the specific surface area and porous skeleton of a heterogeneous catalyst, which differs in the CO2 uptake capacity [12,28–30]. It is the consensus that strategically integrating several multifunctional and synergetic components into one system can achieve greater catalytic performance [31–33]. To this end, our laboratory had covalently integrated porous poly(ionic liquid)s (PPIL) [34–36] with covalent organic frameworks (COF) [37–39] to construct PPIL@COF hybrids of a core-shell structure that exhibits bifunctionality of enhancing CO2 uptake capacity and providing hydrogen bond donor groups at the interface to activate epoxides, thus promoting the catalytic performance of cycloaddition CO2 with epoxides [40] (Fig. S1). However, it's still worthy to be further improved. For instance, the mass transport within the catalyst of a mesoporous structure, especially that between the COF shell and PPIL core, is insufficient. Consequently, the accessibility of PPIL moieties functioning the catalytic active sites is highly limited since they were buried as a core inside the COF shell. We, therefore, envisioned the introduction of proper macropores in the PIL-COF hybrids to construct hierarchical porous structure may both promote the mass transfer on the surface and interface of the catalysts, thus delivering a more efficient catalytic system [41,42]. Herein, we contribute hierarchical porous poly(ionic liquid)s-covalent organic framework (PIL-HPCOF) hybrids as the candidates. The HPCOF backbone therein possesses high surface area and hierarchical porosity to enhance CO2 uptake capacity and facilitate mass transport of either substrates or intermediates, while the linear PIL bearing the catalytic sites threaded throughout to trigger the conversion of CO2 with epoxides. The preparation of such PIL-HPCOF hybrids was accessed via the formation of HPCOF through hard-template method [42], followed by in-situ polymerization of mono-vinyl decorated ILs (Scheme 1 ). Specifically, the polystyrene spheres (PSs) were used as templates to enable the preparation of HPCOF bearing interconnected macropores and intrinsic micropores. In the second step, amino-functionalized linear PIL with abundant bromide anions were introduced into the channels of HPCOF through in-situ free radical polymerization of the corresponding IL monomers. The crystallinity, high surface area and hierarchical porous structure of HPCOF was retained in the resultant PIL-HPCOF hybrids. In particular, the hierarchical porosity could be tuned through the size of PSs launched, while the concentration of catalytic sites per mass could be modulated by the ratio of IL monomer to HPCOF. As a proof of concept, the PIL-HPCOF hybrids displayed excellent catalytic performance, broad applicability, and recyclability in cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides without metal, solvents, or co-catalyst under mild conditions with outstanding yields of selected cyclic carbonate (95∼99%). We attributed the positive effects of such PIL-HPCOF hybrids on the catalytic performance into two aspects. First, the inherent micropores with high surface area and rich nitrogen sites (secondary amine) of COF host improved CO2 concentration around the catalytic sites. Second, the template-induced and interconnected macropores in COF host increased the total pore volume that significantly promoted the mass transfer of substrates and provided more active sites. These results supply the basis to design IL catalysts with high efficiency and stability in the CO2 conversion. 2 Experiment 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of colloidal PS Colloidal PS was prepared according to the literature [43]. Typically, styrene (35 g, 0.34 mol) was purified with aqueous sodium hydroxide (12 mL, 10 wt%) and deionized water (50 mL) before use. Under nitrogen atmosphere, the purified styrene, polyvinylpyrrolidone (1.5 g) and deionized water (300 mL) were added into flask (500 mL) and then reacted at 60 °C for 30 min. Then K2S2O8 (0.5 g) dissolved in deionized water (50 mL) were added into the flask and reacted at 60 °C for 24 h (< 500 r.p.m.). Upon cooling, the PS (320 nm) suspension with a solid content ∼5 wt% were obtained. The colloidal PS was poured into a petri dish at 80 °C to gain the colloidal PS with a solid content ∼10 wt%. Similarly, the colloidal PS with sizes of 160 nm were synthesized by changing the reaction conditions (Table S1). 2.1.2 Synthesis of HP-TpBD HP-TpBD was prepared according to the literature [42]. A mixture of colloidal PS (5 mL, ∼5/10 wt%), p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA, 500 mg, 2.5 mmol) and benzidine (BD, 82.9 mg, 0.45 mmol) in a vial was mixed thoroughly in a vortex shaker for 10 min, followed by adding triformylphloroglucinol (Tp, 0.30 mmol, 63.0 mg) to the vial and further shaking for 30 min. The above yellow mixture was transformed into an open petri dish to evaporate the water naturally and reacted at 120 °C for 48 h in an oven. The red precipitate was washed with hot water (6 × 30 mL) to remove PTSA and then further purified via Soxhlet extraction in THF (100 mL) for 12 h. The dark orange product was dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight to obtain the hierarchical porous TpBD (HP-TpBD-X-Y, X: different sizes of PS spheres; Y: mass fraction of PS spheres). For example, colloidal PS (320 nm) with a solid content of ∼10 wt% were used as template to produce HP-TpBD-320–10. 2.1.3 Synthesis of PIL-HPCOF hybrids To a mixture of HP-TpBD-X-Y (X = 320/160, Y = 5/10) (100 mg) and [AVIM]Br (100/50 mg, 0.46/0.23 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) was added AIBN (10.0 mg) under nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, followed by heating at 90 °C for 72 h. Upon cooling, the solid was collected via filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF (3 × 30 mL), methanol (3 × 30 mL) and acetone (3 × 30 mL), and dried in vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h, which was named as PIL-HPCOF-X-Y-Z (Z: the mass of added [AVIM]Br (mg), 100/50). 2.1.4 Synthesis of PIL-COF-100 hybrids Under nitrogen atmosphere, the mixture of pristine TpBD (100 mg), [AVIM]Br (100.0 mg) and AIBN (10.0 mg) in DMF (2 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 12 h, followed by heating at 90 °C for 72 h. The precipitate was collected via filtration, washed with DMF (3 × 30 mL), methanol (3 × 30 mL) and acetone (3 × 30 mL), and dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight, which was named as PIL-COF-100. 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation and recyclable experiment Typically, propylene oxide (5.0 mmol) and PIL-HPCOF hybrids (5, 10, 15 or 20 mg) were added in a stainless-steel autoclave reactor (20 mL), which was flushed with CO2 for three times and stirred under appointed CO2 atmosphere (0.1, 1.0 or 1.5 MPa) at the required temperature (70, 80 or 90 °C) for a certain time (12, 16, 20 or 24 h). After cool-down, the CO2 in autoclave was gradually released, and PIL-HPCOF hybrids were recovered via centrifugation, washing with dichloromethane and dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 6 h. The liquid phase was evaporated, collected and analyzed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of PIL-HPCOF hybrids The hierarchical porous PIL-HPCOF hybrids were prepared via two steps of hard template method and in-situ polymerization. Initially, the hierarchical porous TpBD (HP-TpBD) was synthesized by the Schiff condensation of 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (Tp) and benzidine (BD) in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) and polystyrene spheres (PSs), wherein PS functions as a hard template and PTSA reacts as a catalyst for the formation of COF skeleton. Next, the HP-TpBD was dispersed in DMF solution containing [AVIM]Br, followed by free-radical polymerization using azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) to produce PIL-HPCOF hybrids. The as-synthesized PIL-HPCOF hybrids were denoted as PIL-HPCOF-X-Y-Z, wherein X denotes the average diameter of PSs (160/320 nm), Y denotes the mass fraction of PSs (5/10), and Z denotes the mass of ILs monomer (50/100 mg) added in the second step. Besides, the pristine TpBD and microporous PIL-COF-Z (Z = 100) were synthesized for comparison. Firstly, the morphology of pristine TpBD, PS and HP-TpBD were studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. 1 ). The pristine TpBD displays random bulk particles with no obvious characteristic morphology (Fig. 1a). The synthetic PSs beads exhibits uniform size at average diameter of ∼160 nm and 320 nm (Fig. 1b and 1c), respectively, suggesting the successful synthesis of PSs template. Using PS beads as the templating agent with a size of 320 nm and a content of 10 wt%, the as-synthesized HP-TpBD-320–10 shows a uniform interconnected macroporous structure after removing PS by Soxhlet extraction with THF (Fig. 1d and 1e). In contrast, the HP-TpBD-320–5 exhibits an inhomogeneous microporous structure with large bulk particle imposed by the less PSs used (Fig. 1f). Similarly, the HP-TpBD-160–10 contains a uniform interconnected macroporous structure by changing the PS templates of different average diameter (Fig. 1g and 1h), which however disappears in the case of small dosage of the same PSs (HP-TpBD-160–5, Fig. 1i). This result indicates a proper amount PSs is crucial to deliver the desired uniform macroporous structure to TpBD skeleton. The SEM analysis on PIL-HPCOF-320/160–10 was next performed (Fig. 2 a and 2b) and compared with the parent HP-TPBD-320/160–10 (Fig. 1d and 1g). Evidently, the morphologic changes are indistinguishable by introducing the guest PIL, preliminarily indicating the polymerization of IL monomer ([AVIM]Br) occurs mostly within the microporous channels of HP-TPBD rather than outside the surface or at the macroporous sites. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements on PIL-HPCOF-320/160–10 further illustrates the interconnected porous structures (Fig. 2c and 2d), which is supposed beneficial to the mass diffusion of substrates for a heterogeneous catalysis. Moreover, the elemental mapping characterization via TEM corresponds the homogeneously distributed bromine element (Fig. 2e), indicating that PIL were uniformly distributed in the HP-TpBD. The crystallinity of these materials was also investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. To investigate the effects of hierarchical porosity and PIL laying within the channel on the crystallinity, porosity, composition of PIL-HPCOF hybrids, the pristine TpBD, HP-TpBD-320–10, PIL-COF-100, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 and individual PIL were taken as the representative samples and were discussed thoroughly. As shown in Fig. 3 , both pristine TpBD and HP-TpBD-320–10 exhibits intensive peaks at 3.6° assigned to the (100) facet, indicating the introduction of macroporous structure via the PS template strategy does not destroy the crystallinity of TpBD. Besides, the PXRD pattern of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 matches with that of the parent HP-TpBD-320–10, while the intensity of the (100) peak relatively decreases for the PIL-HPCOF hybrids. It demonstrates the crystalline structure of HP-TpBD preserves in the PIL-HPCOF hybrids after introducing the linear PIL. However, the presence of flexible carbon chains of PIL in the pores of HP-TpBD slightly distorts the long-range order of crystalline material. Likewise, PIL-COF-100 without macroporous structure also displays weak intensity at (100) peak. In contrast, the individual PIL shows an amorphous feature. N2 sorption analysis at 77 K was conducted to inspect the porosity of representative samples (Fig. 4 and Table 1 ). As expected, the isotherm of pristine TpBD displays type I isotherm representing rapid N2 uptake at P/P0 < 0.1, indicating its microporosity. As for HP-TpBD-320–10, it shows type I isotherm at the lower-pressure range, while the adsorption of N2 is obviously increased at the higher-pressure range. It's attributed to that the presence of additional macropores through PS-template methods. Correspondingly, the pore volume at P/P0 = 0.99 of HP-TpBD-320–10 (0.78 cm3/g) increases significantly as compared to that of pristine TpBD (0.37 cm3/g). However, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area in the case of HP-TpBD-320–10 (535 m2/g) is almost the same as that of pristine TpBD (572 m2/g). These results suggest the porosity of pristine TpBD in HP-TpBD is preserved. Next, the decreased values in BET surface area, pore size and total volume for PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 (174 m2/g, 1.3 nm, and 0.39 cm3/g) confirms that the channel of HP-TpBD-320–10 (535 m2/g, 2.0 nm, and 0.78 cm3/g) is partially occupied by PIL (Fig. S2). Still, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 displays an obvious hierarchical porosity as that of HP-TpBD-320–10. In comparison, PIL-COF-100 behaves comparable values of BET surface area, pore size and pore volume (222 m2/g, 1.4 nm, and 0.16 cm3/g). But it consists of no macroporous structure. Besides, the amorphous linear PIL displays the lowest uptake of N2 and possesses poor BET surface area and pore volume of only 1 m2/g and 0.01 cm3/g, respectively. The structure of PIL-HPCOF hybrids were further investigated by solid state 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 5 ). HP-TpBD-320–10 features two typical 13C resonances assigned to the CO and CN of the keto form at about 184 and 147 ppm, respectively [44, 45]. Besides these peaks, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 still contains high-field peaks at 54, 49 and 40 ppm originated from the alkyl-C species of PIL, indicating the successful integration of PIL with HP-TpBD. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was thereafter conducted for PIL, HP-TpBD-320–10 and PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 (Fig. 6 ). The N 1 s spectra of PIL features two peaks located at 401.5 eV and 399.2 eV originated from the nitrogen atoms of imidazolium and amino, respectively (Fig. 6a) [32]. As expected, that of HP-TpBD-320–10 shows one peak centered at 399.6 eV assigned to the secondary N. In comparison, the N1s spectrum of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 can be resolved into three components attributed to the N atoms of imidazolium at 401.5 eV, amino groups at 399.2 eV originated from PIL, and secondary N at 399.6 eV from HP-TpBD-320–10, respectively. Besides, the Br 3d XPS spectra of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was compared with that of PIL (Fig. 6b). Both feature the characteristic band at 68.8 eV (Br 3d5/2) and 67.8 eV (Br 3d3/2), confirming the presence of bromide anion in PIL-HPCOF hybrids [46]. The content of catalytic sites (bromide anions) in PIL-HPCOF hybrids was also investigated by elemental analysis (Table S2). Moreover, the value of an individual PIL and COF was also examined for comparison. The mass fraction of bromine in PIL is up to 31.45 wt%, while no bromine was detected in HP-TpBD. For the PIL-HPCOF hybrids, the bromine content depends on the dosage of [AVIM]Br for polymerization, also corresponding to the mass fraction of PIL loaded. Specifically, the bromine content of PIL-HPCOF-X-10–100 (X = 320, 10.47 wt%; X = 160, 10.09 wt%) outweighs that of PIL-HPCOF-X-10–50 (X = 320, 6.36 wt%; X = 160, 6.11 wt%). As a result, the calculated loadings of IL unit therein for PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–50, PIL-HPCOF-160–10–100 and PIL-HPCOF-160–10–50 were 1.31 mmol/g, 0.80 mmol/g, 1.26 mmol/g and 0.76 mmol/g, respectively. We also found the absence of macroporous structure does not affect the content of bromine per unit. For example, PIL-COF-100 contains bromine with 1.35 mmol/g, which is equivalent to that of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100. The thermal stability of PIL-HPCOF composite was examined using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under nitrogen environment (Fig. S3). Both PIL and HP-TpBD-320–10 show a single weight-loss stage at 260∼350 °C and 345∼460 °C, which attributed to the decomposition of ionic moieties in PIL and TpBD backbone, respectively. By contrast, two apparent weight loss stages were found in the TGA curves of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100. The first weight loss in the range of 255∼340 °C is attributed to loss of ionic moieties, while the second weight loss within the scope of 340∼470 °C is imposed by the disintegration of skeleton. The gas adsorption properties of PIL, HP-TpBD-320–10 and PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 in terms of CO2 and N2 were examined at the relative pressures of up to 1.0 bar at 273 K and 298 K (Fig. 7 ). As illustrated in Fig. 7a, HP-TpBD-320–10 exhibits the highest CO2 adsorption performance with 1.75 mmol/g at 273 K and 1.0 bar, while PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 performs poorly with 0.73 mmol/g. The relatively decreased CO2 adsorption capacity for the latter is mainly attributed to both partial pore filling and mass increment upon the introduction of PIL. Moreover, the individual PIL shows the lowest CO2 uptake amount of 0.14 mmol/g at 273 K under 1.0 bar due to its low BET surface area and poor porosity. For all samples, the CO2 uptake amount was obviously reduced at 298 K and 1.0 bar (Fig. 7b). Besides, they display lower uptake capacity toward N2 as compared to that of CO2 under identical conditions. Specifically, the N2 uptake values for PIL, HP-TpBD-320–10 and PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 at 273 K under 1 bar (Fig. 7c) are recoded as 0.02, 0.04 and 0.10 mmol/g, respectively. To our delight, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 behaves excellent CO2 absorption cycle-ability (Fig. 7d). Collectively, compared with the individual PIL, PIL-HPCOF hybrids exhibits superior uptake and selectivity toward CO2. It's not only because of the good crystallinity, proper surface area, and the presence of microporosity in space but also the high density of Lewis basic N sites therein to enhance the interaction with acidic CO2 on a molecular level. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation of PIL-HPCOF composites The catalytic evaluation of hierarchical porous PIL-HPCOF composites were subsequently investigated for the cycloaddition reaction between epoxides and CO2 without any solvents, co-catalysts, and additives. Herein, the coupling of propylene oxide (5 mmol) with CO2 catalyzed by PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was taken as the benchmark reaction. The reaction conditions including catalyst dosage (5∼20 mg), reaction temperature (70∼90 °C), CO2 pressure (0.1∼1.5 MPa) and reaction time (12∼24 h) were preliminary examined to obtain the optimum performance in the formation of propylene carbonate. The catalyst dosage (5∼20 mg) on the performance of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was first examined under 1.5 MPa CO2 at 90 °C for 24 h. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the yield of propylene carbonate increased from 65% to 99% as the amount of catalyst increased from 5 mg to 15 mg, followed by reaching to equilibrium though increasing the amount of catalyst. An excellent result was obtained when 15 mg PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was used, providing propylene carbonate with 99% yield after 24 h under 1.5 MPa CO2 pressure. Next, the varying temperature in the range of 70∼90 °C was tested under 1.5 MPa CO2 for 24 h with 15 mg catalyst loading. The yield of propylene carbonate was significantly enhanced from 58% to 99% with reaction temperature from 70 °C to 90 °C (Fig. 8b). Furthermore, the effects of the CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition reaction performance were also studied at 90 °C for 24 h with 15 mg catalyst and the results were shown in Fig. 8c. The yield of product had reached a better value (90%) under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure in the model reaction. It was found that catalytic performance improved with raising CO2 pressure from 0.1 MPa to 1.0 MPa. It provided propylene carbonate with a yield above 99% under 1.0 MPa. Subsequently, the reaction time with 12∼24 h was investigated at 90 °C under 1.0 MPa (Fig. 8d). With the extension of the reaction time (12∼24 h), the yield (75%∼99%) of propylene carbonate increased gradually. As a result, propylene carbonate was obtained with an excellent yield of 99% from propylene oxide (5 mmol) and CO2 (1.0 MPa) in the presence of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 (15 mg) at 90 °C for 24 h. Next, cross experiments on investigating the performance of various PIL-COF hybrids with different catalytic sites content and porosity were conducted under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 2 ). Meanwhile, the catalytic performance of individual PIL and TpBD were also evaluated for comparation. For PIL-HPCOF hybrids, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 exhibits the best catalytic performance, delivering propylene carbonate with 99% yield (entry 1). In comparison, the performance of PIL-COF-100, which contains the same bromide content as that of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100, decreases slightly (entry 2). It suggests the presence of homogeneously dispersed but interconnected macropores in the catalyst structure positively influences the catalytic efficiency probably by enhancing the mass transfer and the accessibility of catalytic sites to reactants during the reaction. Likewise, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 remarkably outperforms the amorphous PIL with the same bromide content (entry 1 vs. 3). The catalytic performance of PIL-COF-100 was significantly improved compared to pure PIL (entry 2 vs. 3), which was mainly attributed to high BET surface area (222 m2/g vs. 1 m2/g), pore volume (0.16 cm3/g vs. 0.01 cm3/g) and CO2 uptake (0.80 mmol/g (Fig. S4) vs. 0.14 mmol/g at 273 K under 1.0 bar). It further demonstrates that the performance of PIL-HPCOF hybrids depends on a combination of the porosity, CO2 uptake and the content of active sites therein. For instance, both PIL-HPCOF-320–10–50 (entry 4) and PIL-HPCOF-160–10–50 (entry 6) provide propylene carbonate with decreased yields due to the less catalytic sites decorated (entry 4 vs. 1; entry 6 vs. 1). Besides, PIL-HPCOF-160–10–100 with different size of macropores displays a comparable reactivity to that of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 (entry 5 vs. 1), suggesting the macropores in both cases are sufficient for mass transfer. Moreover, the performance of a physical mixture of HP-TpBD-320–10 and PIL is also examined, which offers propylene carbonate with only 78% yield due to the incompetent cooperation between two parts by spatial segmentation (entry 7). This result also demonstrates the homogeneous distribution of PIL consisting of active sites into the channels of hierarchical porous TpBD by in-situ polymerization is conductive to the cyclization efficiency. As expected, both HP-TpBD-320–10 and pristine TpBD perform poorly (entries 8 and 9), which is comparable to that without catalyst (entry 10). In conclusion, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 displays the best catalytic performance among all samples, producing propylene carbonate with 99% yield at 90 °C for 24 h with 1.0 MPa CO2 pressure. Noteworthily, compared with the previously reported core-shell PPIL@COF (PPIL@COFA-40) hybrids by our laboratory [40], the performance of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 is much better with the same catalyst dosage. Remarkably, it enables the reaction proceeds at the reduction of temperature by 10 °C and under lower CO2 pressure of 1 MPa. We attribute this improvement to the versatility of hierarchical porous of PIL-HPCOF hybrids to enhance CO2 enrichment around catalytic centers and accelerate mass transfer of substrates. The substrate scope of this newly developed protocol was next studied using PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 as the catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The cyclization of ethylene oxide, epichlorohydrin and epibromohydrin with CO2 at 90 °C for 24 h provides the respective product with excellent yields of 99%, 95% and 96%. Dimethyl, ethyl and phenyl substituted epoxides are also found tolerated. However, it is necessary to extend the reaction time to obtain high yields. Besides, the comparison of the catalytic performance of the previously reported COF-based heterogeneous catalysts, amino-PIL catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts with other carriers and the optimum PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was conducted as that Table 3 shows. Evidently, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 offers the better turnover frequency value under relatively mild conditions among COF-based heterogeneous catalysts (entry 1∼4). Compared to amino-PIL catalysts (entry 5∼6), catalysts with other carrier (entry 7∼8) and our previous work (entry 9), PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 produces excellent yield of propylene carbonate under milder CO2 pressure and reaction temperature, although it possesses lower TOF. A hot leaching test was performed on this catalytic system to investigate the heterogeneous nature of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100. The catalytic reaction was stopped after 12 h, followed by the filtration to remove the PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100. No further reaction occurred in the absence of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 with additional 12 h, indicative of heterogeneous nature of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 (Fig. S5). The recyclability of PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was investigated taking the benchmark reaction of propylene oxide with CO2 in consideration (Fig. 10 ). The PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 was separated from reaction solution by centrifugation, washing with CH2Cl2 and drying under vacuum at 80 °C for 6 h for the next run. To our delight, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 can retain its catalytic activity and provide propylene carbonate with a yield up to 94% after five runs. Additionally, the XRD, SEM, N2 sorption and TGA results indicated the crystallinity, morphology, porosity and stability of used PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 were preserved and considered as a renewable and stable catalyst (Fig. S6∼S9). Based on the theoretical basis and our results [14,48], a speculative mechanism for the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 catalyzed by PIL-HPCOF hybrids is presented in Fig. S10. Initially, the epoxide was activated through hydrogen bond of PIL. Meanwhile, the nucleophilic bromide anions attacked the β-carbon of the epoxide. Subsequently, CO2 enriched from COF host with porosity and rich basic sites was activated by amino groups, followed by the reaction between activated CO2 and ring-opened epoxide to form the intermediate. Finally, the ring-closing reaction occurred to produce the corresponding cyclic carbonate and regenerated catalyst for the next cycle. 4 Conclusions In summary, the fabrication of poly(ionic liquid)-hierarchical porous covalent organic framework (PIL-HPCOF) hybrids was accessed through the construction of hierarchical porous COF skeleton via hard-template method, followed by introduction of linear PILs into the channels via in-situ free-radical polymerization. The numbers per volume and size of the macropores in PIL-HPCOF hybrids can be adjusted by the average diameter and mass percentage of the PS templates, while the buried catalytic sites per mass unit is modulated by the dosage of IL monomer for polymerization. Taking the cyclization of epoxides with CO2 as the benchmark reaction, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 displays excellent catalytic performance under mild conditions in the absence of any co-catalyst, which delivers cyclic carbonates with high yields (95∼99%) and broad functionality scope. As confirmed by experiments, the excellent versatility possessed by PIL-HPCOF hybrids is mainly attributed to the hierarchical porous structures, with micropores providing high surface area to enhance CO2 uptake capacity and macropores supplying sufficient pore volume to promote mass transport of substrates. Remarkably, it offers high reactivity over previously reported core-shell PPIL@COF hybrids, which signifies the importance of the mass transfer for the benchmark reaction. Besides, PIL-HPCOF-320–10–100 behaves good reusability without significant activity loss via simple separation process. The construction of efficient IL-based catalysts towards CO2 conversion based on this newly developed novel design concept is now carried out in our lab. coredata.dc:description: The chemical fixation of CO2 into high value-added chemicals is of significant potential and sustainability to address the energy and ecological issues. To achieve great catalytic performance on the transformation of CO2, it is pivotal to strategically integrating several multifunctional and synergetic functionalities into the catalyst design and catalytic system construction. Herein, the poly(ionic liquid)-hierarchical porous covalent organic framework (PIL-HPCOF) hybrids were successfully synthesized via the formation of HPCOF through hard-template method, followed by in-situ polymerization of mono-vinyl decorated ionic liquids (ILs). The resultant PIL-HPCOF hybrids possess excellent versatility, with micropores providing high surface area to enhance CO2 uptake capacity and macropores supplying sufficient pore volume to promote mass transport of substrates. As a proof of concept, the conversion of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates was selected as a model reaction, which catalytic performance was obviously promoted by using PIL-HPCOF hybrids as the catalyst as compared to those of independent PIL and the PIL-COF hybrids with only micropores. Thus, it enables such a metal-free catalysis proceeds under much mild conditions (CO2 (1 MPa), 90 °C) and with broad substrates tolerance. These results supply the basis to design efficient and stable catalysts for CO2 conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilization poly(ionic liquid)s into hierarchical porous covalent organic frameworks as heterogeneous catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides
